summary: The document is a confidential communication from the Chief/OCC to a station, seeking assistance in contacting a former employee in Costa Rica, as part of compliance with the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992. This Act requires the public release of all assassination-related documents, including names of individuals mentioned, unless specific exceptions are met. The document details the stringent process and criteria for postponing the release of such information, highlighting the necessity for compelling evidence of harm to national security or personal safety to prevent disclosure.
key_findings: The document is part of efforts to comply with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992, aiming for transparency by releasing related documents to the public.

Names of individuals in these documents will be released unless it can be proven that disclosure poses a credible threat to their safety, national security, or violates privacy to an extent that outweighs public interest.
The process for preventing the release of names is stringent, requiring clear and convincing evidence to a Presidentially-appointed board, with very few exceptions granted.
The document provides guidance to individuals whose names appear in these records, explaining the implications of disclosure and the limited options available to prevent it.
